Eurotrip — 10 days, 5 countries, 85k INR

All your dreams can come true if only you have the courage to pursue them — Disney :D

For all the dreamers out there who wish to visit Europe but are still wondering how to go about it, we would like to share our experience with you in a hope that this will help you to live your travel dreams. In this blog we will give you an overview of our recent Eurotrip where we visited 5 countries in 10 days with 85,000 INR budget per person. Details of our experience in each city to be shared in separate posts soon!

For 10-days EuroTrip, below should be your checklist:

  1. Valid Passport
  2. Schengen Visa (matching your travel dates)
  3. Approx. 85K INR in your account. A Debit/Credit card that can work internationally
  4. Travel Itinerary and hotel bookings — Hard & soft copy
  5. HERE Maps & Google Maps apps, for offline navigation
  6. An awesome company ;)
    (You surely can #gosolo but a good company is really helpful)

Starting with the passport, we assume that before you plan for your first Eurotrip, you do have a valid passport available with atleast two blank pages in it. If not, the first thing you need to do is to apply for the same through:
http://www.passportindia.gov.in/AppOnlineProject/welcomeLink

Second step and the most crucial one is to obtain a Schengen Visa for your travel. Getting a short term Tourism Schengen Visa is easy & quick to get if only you apply appropriately and submit the correct documents. We have explained the visa application process along with the list of documents required in separate post and can be found here: https://medium.com/@4eyedexperience/getting-schengen-visa-eurotrip-34426ea6a615

Thirdly, the expenses! Now this is something which is little bit flexible. Based on your interest and affordability you can make changes to this. We will be sharing our itinerary and expense breakup for your reference:

Trip Duration — 31st March to 9th April 2017(30 March) Bangalore>Mumbai> Amsterdam> Innsbruck> Venice> Prague> Paris> Amsterdam>Mumbai> Bangalore(10th April)

Return Tickets from Bangalore to Amsterdam — 33,000 INR
Insurance + Visa + Photo Cost — 1000 + 5800 + 100 (6900) INR
Internal Travel in Europe: 10,000 INR (Flight + Train + Bus)
Per day Cost, Stay + Food + Travel Around: 1200+ 1000 + 1000 INR
Shopping (Souvenirs)+ Leisure+ Theme Park (Disneyland): 13000 INR

For the return flight tickets, we realized that the tickets from Mumbai are cheaper than from Bangalore, hence booked return flight tickets from Mumbai to Amsterdam, costing us close to 33,000 INR via Paytm. We got 10% cashback which actually covered our return flight tickets cost from Bangalore to Mumbai. Visa Fees are fixed and will cost close to 6800, including insurance. We planned to visit 5 cities in 5 different countries giving us a flavor of 5 different themes. We used https://www.goeuro.com/ , https://www.booking.com/ and http://www.hostelworld.com/ to book our internal travel and accommodation. If planned early, you surely can manage to get all these booked in similar amount like ours. If you check the intra-Europe travel price you will find that flights can be booked from 1500 INR, Trains from 1800 INR and Buses from 2000 INR. These are all dynamic in nature, however even upto two weeks before you can get good price. So no need to make your intra-europe bookings before you get your Schengen Visa. Important tip, in Europe you are charged additionally for check-in baggage in flights. Hence if you can travel with single back pack you can save some money but of course then you need to fit everything in your single bag.

For accommodation, note that in some cases, hotels cost cheaper than hostels if you have a companion to share the hotel costs. One of the many reason why you should consider going with a good company instead of going solo. For food, we were both vegetarians and the best option for us there was Subway/Veg Pizza. Fortunately both these cost close to INR 500 per meal (30 inch sub/ 12 inch Veg Pizza) in almost everywhere. Sometimes we did walked a long distance to find the restaurant that suits our eating habit and our wallet but it was totally worth it. Also we got ourselves some chocolates, peanuts, chips from India to munch in between our meals which helped us to easily survive on two meals a day.

Coming to travel within the city, we usually covered most of it by walking and if required, traveled in public transport using one time tickets instead of buying 24 hour pass. Honestly, they are really overpriced and you never are able to utilize it fully. So we will be suggesting you to take a city map from your hotel/hostel and explore the city by walking. We particularly are big fan of seeing the beauty of the city, architecture, landscapes art and culture. So we didn’t spend time in museums or churches which did help us to not incur additional expense in terms of entrance fees. However, if you are interested in Museums and Churches, please do consider to have additional resources (time and money,approx INR 250 + 1 hour for each). Lastly, Europe does offer you range of products to shop for yourselves and your dear ones. Based on your shopping budget and space in your baggage, restrict yourself. Do collect souvenirs from every place you visit (usually costs ~150 INR per item)
We did go to Disneyland Paris which costed us 5600 INR and was the only expensive leisure item that we took during our trip.

Even after planning everything perfectly you can still come across situation where you will have to make some unplanned expenses. Don’t panic in those moments, they are just part and parcel of adventurous trips ;)

Lastly, few tips for your travel that helped us a lot: Do download Google Maps and HERE maps from google play store and make the regions that you will be visiting as offline in your mobile. They are very handy for navigation in the city. Especially HERE maps as it also shows public transport options even in offline more. Secondly, don’t keep all your money/cards/passport at same place. Usually leave your passport in your hotel/hostels and carry your driving license for ID proof everywhere as it is widely accepted. Also, no need to carry a lot of Euros while travelling as almost every place accept the cards. We carried 100 euros with us and were able to survive the whole of 10 days with that much of cash. While travelling it is good to keep a set of hard copies for all your bookings and also keep the soft copies of them all on cloud storage. Lastly but most importantly, do carry a good camera/ camera phone and a power bank to click each and every beautiful moment of your journey.

Hope this post will be helpful to give you a heads-up for planning your first Euro-trip. We will be sharing the details of each of the 5 cities we visited in separate posts soon. Meanwhile if you have any queries or suggestions please feel free to drop us a line at: 4eyedexperience@gmail.com

We love to make faces and click pictures as we travel. If you would like to have a glimpse, below is our Instagram profile:

https://www.instagram.com/4eyedexperience/
